comments.commentBody: No doubt the parents and ultimately the child will be OFFENDED when others don't realize that the child is male or female.

That's incredibly authoritarian on the part of Germany.

Why should anyone be *forced* to reveal their, or their child's, gender? To me, that's like a law forcing people to reveal their or their child's race, skin color, or ethnicity. Or sexual orientation! Especially when so many people today are finally questioning the social construct of gender, and transsexual rights have finally made it onto the media radar, how can one's gender be anyone's business aside from one's sexual partner(s) (if any) and one's doctor (if one has a disease related to one's sex organs, sex chromosomes, or sex hormones).

Astounding that today's German people, who generally seem at such pains to avoid repeating the fascism of their country's recent past, haven't protested such a law, or even allowed it to be passed in the first place.

Just for info, Hayden is the last name of the man who funded the planetarium which bears his name.
Neil DeGrasse Tyson is its director.
These are great names....if you want your kid to come home from school with black eyes every day.
I enjoyed your name list from the past!
Hey, you skipped the 1960s! There were a ton of Nancys in my graduating class (birth year 1962), and no one gets named that anymore. Also Sandy, Barb, Tammy, etc. Naming definitely goes in cycles.

"One of many problems with trendy names is that they'll eventually "date" their owners"

This is a normal, inevitable occurrence as time marches on. Why does it worry you?

One of many problems with trendy names is that they'll eventually "date" their owners, which will start becoming particularly burdensome when they reach their mid-30s, 40s and 50s, especially for girls (who also bear the misfortune of having fashion hold a much tighter grip on their naming than that of their brothers in the first place).

Ask:

- the Sophronias, Orphenias & Aurelias of the 1800-10 era,
- the Agathas, Agneses, Myrtles, Adelaides, Ediths, Oras, Mabels, Gertrudes, Maudes & Berthas of the 1880s,
- the Dollies, Daisies, Sadies, Fannies, Flossies, Belles & Mamies of the 1890s,
- the Roses, Idas, Ellas, & Esthers of the 1900s
- the Ednas, Mildreds, Effies, Myras, Elsies, Ruths, Ettas, Eunices, Eulas, Hazels, Netties, Pearls, Gladyses, Minnies, Millies & Rubys of the 1920s,
- the Lornas, Lolas, Loises, Estelles, Lucilles, & Avas (yes, back in fashion today) of the 1940s,
- the Rhondas, Suzies, Stellas, Blanches, Bettys, Brendas & Thelmas of the 1950s,
- the Courtneys, Ambers, Jennas, Ashleys & Tiffanys of the 1980s

and, one day,

- the Madisons, Kylies and Kaitlyns of the 2000s and
- the Olivias, Sophias and Avas of the 2010s.

Today's cute, aspirational, "original," "different," "modern" name will one day be associated with the dread middle-aged set. In the 2050s, "Madison" will be the "Mom Jeans"-wearing embarrassment that "Rhonda" is (to trendy, fashion-conscious parents) today.

The kids  of Chinese immigrants my son went to middle school with, in the 90's, had the names of the previous generation of white/Jewish adults of our area (Queens), like Irene, Beverly, Mary, Victor, Stanley, Walter. No idea why these old-fashioned names were particularly attractive to this group!
In China, many given names, perhaps most, are gender neutral. I frequently met people there whose given name was Ming, meaning "bright." I suppose Claire and Clarence are the English analogs of Ming.

It is all' very relative: Simone and Andrea are names for girls in Germani
while they are very much boys name in Italy....
My friend has a son named Darwin

It is disingenuous of Schrodinger to invoke Yosemite. Yosemite Valley was indeed a California State Park before it was a National Park, but that was only the Valley, not the vast swath of high Sierra that is in today's national park. And the State did a poor job of keeping up its park, which is why Californians lobbied their own State to revert the Valley into the National Park.

Nor are the areas of controversy today some "semi-arid parts of Nevada". There are recent attempts in Congress to give away a National Wildlife Refuge in Puerto Rico:

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/17/opinion/dont-give-away-our-wildlife-re...

Schrodinger, areas that don't look spectacularly beautiful can still be valuable. For instance, Cheyenne Bottoms probably would look ordinary to you, but it's an important stopover point for the Whooping Cranes as they migrate south each year. I believe the lands that Cliven Bundy and friends want to take over are also bird sanctuaries.

Our public lands have multiple uses. They are the source of our uncontaminated drinking water. And sometimes a rare plant is discovered to have properties that make possible a medical breakthrough. But if the public land the plant grows on is privatized and overgrazed, the plant may be destroyed before the medical use is even discovered.

Also, it isn't correct to talk about federal lands or federal control. They are public lands, and belong to all of us.

"The areas where there is controversy over Federal control are semi-arid parts of Nevada. Those areas look nothing like the pictures that Kristof has posted."

And your point is?

I've spent many a wondrous night camping on the Great Plains (National Grasslands) of New Mexico and Colorado. Don't imply certain natural places are worth protecting while others are not.

I hiked a short section of the John Muir Trail last week. I've posted some pictures on my blog at the link below.

https://schrodingerblog.blogspot.com/2016/08/some-pictures-from-john-mui...

The argument that 'these lands are under threat from Republicans' is a standard liberal meme. It is very disingenuous of Kristof to link this to national parks. Yosemite was a California state park before it was a national park, with the initial land grant signed by President Lincoln. The state of California will protect our High Sierra even if the federal government doesn't.

The areas where there is controversy over Federal control are semi-arid parts of Nevada. Those areas look nothing like the pictures that Kristof has posted.

.
JFC, when this happens again -- and I think we all know the question is not "if", but "when" -- I want you to take some Vitamin B Complex or Vitamin C Complex, put on some Allman Brothers, and do whatever else Dan Aykroyd recommends here:

http://www.hulu.com/watch/4131 [no Hulu membership required, but you have to sit through one commercial]

Talk about phoning it in.

You have an audience of MILLIONS, Ms. Dowd.
Please try to keep them by actually writing something next time.
Actually, now I know the difference too, John.  Don't worry.  I shant tell.
(a cameo in the finale I should say)
Missed the triple wordplay: Blue's downer blues.

Bottom half of the puzzle went ok, then the NE took a little while but managed to get it with IMAX. Terrible time in the NW, had to ultimately get help from the blog with AZALEATREE (which I kind of had in the back of my mind somehow with the L, but can't explain it). My downfall was sticking with BLEU instead of thinking AZUR. When the tree bloomed out, my blueing (downer blues?) problem became obvious, and the rest filled in quickly.

I never worry about what I've heard of before, just what could make sense and fills the squares in a reasonable and often satisfying way (just "clicks"). These late-weeks are always difficult for me with the variable clue pitching speeds. (Someone should write a research paper on cognition from all the blog responses from everyone.)

(RERUNS finally as the satisfying answer to those recent clues, and Star Trek's Mr Atoz makes a cameo!)

Krugman talks about the gridlock we never cared about. Wrong gridlock!

Keynes did make reference to ides such that infrastructure spending was necessary in the long run and it that it made economic sense to treat these as investments on par with other capitalistic investments. That is, we should think of these investments on par with business investments that produce gains. He was just wrong if that is what he was talking about.

But what about the other claim, that this recession is just artificial and that we can move up the GDP with a deliberate attempt? We can move it up while it exists, but is it like sugar like Geithner believed? It depends upon context.

Basing a science upon such horrible evidence as economics has is an affront to real science. Given global economics, I think almost every economist in existence is pretty ignorant including Krugman.

Why didn't this field ever try to do better? Perhaps college is the problem. Perhaps we need new non-profit entities that attempt to foster new thought in young people (12-20) in both social 'sciences', engineering and science.

If I make some money, it will be directed towards this. Almost everyone trying today is doing the wrong things, fostering the wrong instincts in us.

Competition is fine, but competition between cooperative organizations is something we don't know how to cater. We have not even begun to build reasonable societies. We have not even begun to understand human circumstances.

If it goes away in one to three weeks, then it is far less devastating than the many things that don't go away.

Because of the damage done to a baby, of course we need to have a vaccine, and of course we should eradicate the virus as near as possible. That should be a high priority. There is no slightest excuse for inaction. It is basic public health.

However, it is not "a threat to our ability to have healthy children" for an entire generation. Three weeks of vulnerability is not the end of the world.

Ought a woman who gets this virus during pregnancy then terminate that pregnancy? That is an incredibly painful question. That we even ask it highlights the priority this deserves. But that does not justify "we'll never have kids" hyperventilation.

No Mark, I don't have a crystal ball. I don't know what Hillary will or won't accomplish as President but I suspect she will be one of our hardest working Presidents and will be trying her best to make her mark as the first woman elected to our highest office. I hope she does a good job. But, if she doesn't, she certainly can't muck it up any more than many of the men have.
As for your remark "she will do more of what she has always done, always without exception." Most of the time when "always" or "never" are used in a statement, it isn't a credible statement.
One of my major concerns is about Supreme Court judges and I do trust Hillary to make good choices in this area. Those judges will be influencing policy long after Hillary retires.
(a cameo in the finale I should say)

Malaria is a parasite, not a virus. That is why a vaccine has not emerged, they are anti-viral and it isn't viral. The only similarity is that mosquitoes carry it.

We turn out a new flu vaccine every year, on a few months' notice from its evolution in China. We can in fact do a rapid vaccine for the Zika virus, if not as fast as a flu we understand so well, then still pretty fast.

I also stopped reading Dowd's columns a while ago but this headline seemed interesting. I was fooled again. Mo has again seemed to fill he column with nothing worth while, as usual.  From now on I will read columnists who have something new and interesting to say.
I no longer read her columns.  I just read the comments about them.  They give me the gist (always more than annoying) and are much more factual and entertaining.
I gave up reading Maureen Dowd's columns a while back but decided to give her another chance. I remember now why I stopped reading her writings.

Martin, Rex's bottom line was -- "Hope you enjoyed it more than I did." You might not know this but he already dissed one Jeff Chen puzzle this week. I don't think he wanted to do it twice.

Martin, I'm beginning to see a correlation between the insiders NYT and the insiders Washington, DC.

The difference in medal tally by country clearly reflects the more broader economic and social disparity in our globalised world today. But then again to see a country like Jamaica or Ethiopia win all those medals give us all hope that somehow raw talent and grit can overcome tremendous systemic odds. I am an Indian and so proud of our two girls who are bringing home medals and the other Olympians who tried!

Well, they were distracted enough to bother qualifying and SENDING athletes to the Games.  So your argument is pretty silly.  I'd say, equivalent to an 11th-place finish.  Certainly nowhere near the medal platform.

Actually if you count the number of people who train in the US, medal count would be even less for many of these countries.  It really goes to show how much infrastructure is available here and I can say that as an immigrant!
.00001% of a billion is 100. There are more than 100 top athletes in India.

The pretty young woman from Croatia who won the gold in javelin is an excellent example of your point.  Diminutive compared to the silver and bronze winners, but man, what an athletic gold-medal-winning throw!  Watch it in slow-mo if you get a chance.
